I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During a mission fielded in August 2010, the Government of Indonesia and the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) agreed on the objective, scope, and implementation and financing 
arrangements  for  capacity  development  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  public–private 
partnerships (PPPs). The TA is designed to support the realization of the impacts and outcomes 
of the Infrastructure Reform Sector Development Program (IRSDP).1 The IRSDP highlights a 
number of important gaps that need to be resolved to make the overall program fully effective, 
particularly in preparing and structuring PPP projects with government contracting agencies 
(GCAs). The TA will provide capacity development assistance to bridge these gaps. The TA is 
in  line  with  (i)  ADB’s  country  strategy  for  Indonesia,2 and  (ii)  ADB’s  long-term  strategic 
framework expectation for greater ADB involvement in private sector development.3 The design 
and monitoring framework is presented in Appendix 1.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Significant  infrastructure  investment  requirements.  Following  the  Asian  financial 
crisis, Indonesia cancelled or suspended many of its planned public and private infrastructure 
projects. Infrastructure investment has since fallen from approximately 6% of gross domestic 
product to a low of 2% of GDP in 2000, before recovering to the current level of 4% of gross 
domestic product. Despite this improvement, infrastructure investment is still low by international 
standards, with levels tending to be in the range of 6%—7% for high growth economies in Asia.5 
The government is seeking to mobilize approximately $140 billion of investment in infrastructure 
over the next 5 years.  
 
3.  Public sector constraints. The ability of the public sector to meet these investment 
requirements  is  limited  by  its  macroeconomic  objectives  to  keep  public  sector  debt  at  a 
sustainable level and reduce its fiscal deficit. Reflecting these constraints, the government 
anticipates that approximately 60% of its planned infrastructure financing requirements will be 
sourced from the private sector.  
 
4.  ADB assistance. The government recognizes that private sector participation cannot be 
taken for granted, and that major structural and institutional reforms are needed. The IRSDP 
supports a comprehensive medium-term reform agenda that has been successful in opening 
infrastructure to private sector participation. The third and final subprogram loan for the IRSDP 
is being presented to the ADB Board of Directors for approval in December 2010.  
 
5.  Indonesia  Infrastructure  Financing  Facility.  In  2009,  as  part  of  the  overall  PPP 
development  framework,  the  government  and  other  development  partners  established  PT 
Indonesia Infrastructure Finance, which is an infrastructure financing company. The company is 
expected to have a loan portfolio of up to $1.0 billion by 2014. ADB has contributed up to $40 
million of equity, and provided a sovereign loan of up to $100 million to finance the company. PT 
Sarana  Multi  Infrastruktur  (Persero)  (SMI),  a  state-owned  entity,  is  a  shareholder  of  PT

6.  Constraints for project development. While the government has developed a number 
of PPP projects, they have not attracted significant market interest. The main constraints for 
project development relate to (i) the government’s inability to acquire land in the public interest; 
(ii) lack of policy clarity on public sector support for PPP projects; and (iii) lack of effective 
institutional  arrangements  to  properly  prepare,  implement,  monitor,  and  ensure  contract 
compliance for PPPs. The government has taken various actions to resolve these issues: 
 
(i)  Land acquisition. With ADB assistance, the government is in the final stage of 
formulating a draft land acquisition law that is expected to be considered by 
Parliament in early 2011.6 The new law will provide enhanced legal framework for 
the government to acquire land for infrastructure projects.  
 
(ii)  Government support. The government has addressed the second constraint of 
providing  public  sector  support  for  PPPs  by  enacting  a  regulation,  MOF 
regulation Number 38/PMK.01/2006, allowing the government to mitigate political, 
demand, and project performance risks associated with PPP projects through the 
Infrastructure Guarantee Facility, recently established by MOF.  
 
(iii)  Project preparation. ADB is providing assistance to address the third constraint 
of  poor  project  preparation  by  providing  the  National  Development  Planning 
Agency  (BAPPENAS)  with  a  loan  under  the  IRSDP  to  establish  a  project 
development facility to prepare and transact PPP projects.  
 
7.  Future requirements. Despite these efforts, few PPP projects are being developed. 
While land acquisition and government support constraints are being resolved, concerns about 
project design, preparation, and implementation continue. To date, the Project Development 
Facility has had difficulty developing project structures that are efficient and effective, attractive 
to private financiers, and affordable to government. These difficulties are arising due to factors 
such  as  limited  awareness  in  Indonesia  of  alternative  types  of  PPP  structures  being 
implemented in countries such as Australia, India, and Singapore. 
 
8.  Based on international best practice, a wide range of possible PPP structures could be 
used in Indonesia to address the needs of both the government and the private sector. Their 
use requires a project evaluation methodology that develops project structures that demonstrate 
value for money, are bankable, and are affordable to government. This methodology needs to 
reconcile the technical and cost aspects of projects to the government relative to financial 
requirements of financiers and lenders, and affordability constraints of government. The PPP 
methodology  needs  to  be  embedded  in  a  project  design,  preparation,  and  implementation 
process that clearly defines and fully integrates the roles of BAPPENAS, MOF, the Investment 
Coordinating Board (BKPM), and prospective GCAs. As GCAs will be signatories to long-term 
contracts for up to 20–25 years, they need to take responsibility for initiating PPP contracts and 
take the lead in structuring, implementing, and managing the projects. This means that GCAs 
need to understand the nature of project structuring and implementation processes, and access 
assistance to increase their awareness of the methodologies and options available to develop 
and implement successful PPP projects.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The impact of the TA will be improved national and regional provision of infrastructure 
and delivery of services by selected GCAs through the use of PPPs. The TA will support the 
government in preparing PPP projects that are economically sound, financially attractive to 
private sector financiers, and affordable to government.  
 
10.  The outcome of the project will be improved capacity of GCAs to develop, implement, 
and  monitor  infrastructure  PPP  projects.  This  will  support  the  government’s  objective  of 
increasing  the  number  and  value  of  commercially  attractive  and  sustainable  PPP  projects 
offered by GCAs to the private sector. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will be comprised of a preparatory stage, followed by the delivery of the following 
outputs: 
 
(i)   strengthened institutional capacity of selected GCAs to select and design PPP 
project structures and implementation processes; 
(ii)  development  of  two  examples  of  best  practice  PPP  structures  and 
implementation processes; and 
(iii)  increased awareness of GCAs on the requirements to prepare efficient, bankable, 
and affordable PPP projects. 
 
12.  Project preparation. The TA consultants will review existing PPP projects in Indonesia 
and  studies  prepared  by  consultants  financed  under  the  IRSDP  to  identify  lessons  from 
successful PPP projects, and the reasons for their success. The TA consultants will liaise with a 
broad group of stakeholders including GCAs, private sector investors, legal firms, commercial 
banks, and the Infrastructure Guarantee Facility to identify a list of candidate PPP projects. The 
TA will target the priority subsectors of power, roads, water, and waste management; and 
identify two pilot projects. The consultants will apply an agreed list of criteria to identify two 
suitable pilot projects. The following criteria will be used to select the two pilot projects: (i) 
facilitates policy and institutional reform; (ii) reflects the government’s planning requirements; (iii) 
GCA commitment and readiness; (iv) project readiness; (v) project replication potential; and (vi) 
potential for catalyzing private sector interest and commercial financing. They will then prepare 
an implementation plan to develop institutional capacity within the selected GCAs, and submit 
the findings in an inception report.  
 
13.  Strengthened institutional capacity of selected GCAs to select and design PPP 
project  structures  and  implementation  processes.  The  consultants  will  work  with  the 
selected GCAs to develop good governance institutional structures for project preparation, 
implementation, and management. They will help the selected GCAs identify and select relevant 
staff to be responsible for PPP activities, examine capacity building and training needs, prepare 
guidelines,  and  provide  training  in  project  preparation  and  contract  management.  The 
arrangements will be detailed in an institutional capacity building report. 
 
14.  Development of two examples of best practice PPP structures and implementation 
processes. The TA consultants will work with the GCA project preparation teams responsible 
for the design, preparation, transaction, and management of the PPP projects. The consultants

4   
will help develop Outline Business Cases (OBCs) that address the following three interlinked 
activities of a PPP project: 
 
(i)  Technical analysis. This involves the assessment of project rationale, market 
analysis,  output  specification,  viability  and  validity  of  feasibility  and/or 
prefeasibility reports, estimates of project costs and benefits, site enablement 
analysis,  social  and  environmental  safeguards  assessments,  legal  review  of 
assets  and  functions,  economic  analysis,  and  stakeholder  review  to  confirm 
project attractiveness. 
(ii)  Procurement analysis. Develop a financial model; and assess procurement and 
financial  options  based  on  criteria  of  value  for  money,  bankability,  and 
affordability. Conduct government support analysis, and identify a proposed risk 
allocation structure. Conduct market sounding to confirm the project’s financial 
parameters, and evaluate legal and institutional requirements to establish the 
proposed PPP structure. 
(iii)  Project implementation requirements. Develop a project preparation plan to 
address site enablement issues, and confirm the government’s willingness and 
capacity  to  provide  support  to  the  projects. Review  requirements  to  prepare  
(i) bid documents (request for qualification and request for proposal), and draft 
contractual terms; (ii) project pre-bid consultations; (iii) bidder qualification and 
bid evaluation criteria; (iv) detailed output specification, performance indicators, 
and monitoring and evaluation frameworks; (v) required due diligence documents 
and online data requirements; (vi) assistance required for the bid process, bid 
evaluation,  and  contract  negotiation;  (vii)  terms  of  reference  for  transaction 
advisors;  and  (viii)  institutional  requirements  within  GCAs  to  implement  the 
transaction and manage the PPP contract. 
 
15.  Increased awareness of GCAs on the requirements to prepare efficient, bankable, 
and affordable PPP projects. The OBCs and supporting materials will provide the GCAs with a 
set of project evaluation tools, a methodology, checklists, and an implementation process that 
will allow them to develop PPP capacity within the respective GCAs. These case studies, tools, 
and materials will be disseminated to MOF, BAPPENAS, BKPM, and representative GCAs 
through a series of workshops. 
 
16.  Assumptions and risks. The design of the TA is based on the assumptions that the 
government will continue its commitment to pursue development policy to support infrastructure-
led growth, to make government guarantees available, and to have the ability to procure land. In 
addition, sustained fiscal resources must be available for project support. Critical risks include 
the possibility that the government does not enact a new land acquisition law or establish a 
government guarantee facility; slow economic growth that affects business confidence and 
interest in PPPs, and reduced government buy-in during TA implementation. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The  total  cost  of  the  TA  is  estimated  at  $550,000  equivalent,  of  which  $500,000 
equivalent will be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction (JFPR), 
and administered by ADB. The government will finance the remaining $50,000 equivalent in 
kind. Detailed cost estimates and the financing plan are presented in Appendix 2.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  SMI will be the executing agency for the TA. SMI is a state-owned entity, in which MOF 
represents the government as shareholder. A steering committee chaired by the SMI president 
director will be established with representatives from ADB, MOF, BAPPENAS, and BKPM as 
members.  The  steering  committee  will  review  and  approve  the  TA  implementation  plan 
prepared at the end of phase 1 (project screening), and meet on a quarterly basis to provide 
oversight, monitoring, and guidance on TA issues.  
 
19.  Screening of project proposals. SMI will screen the project proposals with assistance 
from the consultants, based on a project proposal application form submitted by the GCAs. After 
SMI  evaluation  and  approval,  the  GCA  will  enter  into  a  project-specific  memorandum  of 
understanding with ADB that defines the use of the funds under the TA and the obligations of 
the GCA to support the project.  
 
20.  Procurement. A team of international and national consultants (firm and/or individuals) 
will implement the TA activities and will be recruited in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The consultants will be requested to 
field a multidisciplinary team to provide financial, commercial, technical (engineering), economic, 
social,  environmental,  legal,  and  procurement  services.  Outline  terms  of  reference  are 
presented in Appendix 3. The consultants will be paid lump sum amounts in accordance with TA 
contract milestones. The GCAs will be required to provide office space, furniture, and logistical 
and administrative support. The TA will be implemented from December 2010 to December 
2011. All equipment and software will be procured in accordance with ADB’s Procurement 
Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time), and will be handed over to the government 
upon completion of the TA. Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
21.  Consultant reports. The consultants will undertake a screening process of a list of 
potential PPP projects provided by ADB and SMI; and within 3 weeks of the start of the TA, 
prepare  an  inception  report  that  describes  the  approach,  timelines,  and  required  approval 
stages.  The  consultants  will  conduct  an  institutional  review,  produce  project  preparation 
guidelines, and submit an institutional capacity building report. The consultants will prepare a 
draft OBC report for each project. The consultants will then prepare a draft final TA report that 
collates the documents, tools, and methodologies used to prepare the OBCs to form a PPP 
toolkit and provide a series of workshop training programs. Workshops will be conducted with 
representatives from SMI, BAPPENAS, MOF, BKPM, and the representative GCAs. Following 
feedback  from  the  workshop  participants  the  consultants  will  finalize  the  TA  report  and 
supporting documents. SMI will disseminate the TA reports at the end of the assignment; project 
evaluation results will be made publicly available on ADB’s website. The TA documents will be 
housed with SMI and used to guide the development of subsequent PPP projects. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to the Government 
of the Republic of Indonesia to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty 
Reduction for Capacity Development Assistance for Public–Private Partnerships, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1  The project’s capacity building efforts will help expand the government's ability to manage 
the  public–private  partnership  (PPP)  process  to  achieve  long-term  project  sustainability  and 
viability by preparing and executing PPP projects that achieve value for money, and are bankable 
and affordable by the government. In addition to direct capacity building, and preparation of case 
studies  of  bankable  PPP  projects,  resources  will  be  used  to  develop  examples  of  the  PPP 
preparation process, procedures, and templates; and disseminate these findings to government 
contracting agencies (GCAs) and other key stakeholders.  
 
2  The consulting firm or consortium will provide services covering (i) financial and commercial 
structuring,  (ii)  technical  (engineering)  analysis,  (iii)  economic  analysis,  
(iv) environmental safeguards, (v) social safeguards, and (vi) legal and procurement aspects. 
Because of the complexity of the PPP transaction support work, a consulting firm or consortium is 
preferred.  If  this  is  not  possible  because  of  market  conditions,  individual  consultants  will  be 
recruited. The work will be closely aligned with the work being performed by consultants engaged 
by the National Development Planning Agency (BAPPENAS) under the project development facility 
financed by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to synergize resources and avoid duplication of 
efforts.  
 
3  The project will be implemented by a consulting firm or consortium: 7 person-months of 
international and 20 person-months national, and unallocated person-months to be provided as 
needed.  The  consultants  will  be  remunerated  on  a  lump  sum  basis  on  the  achievement  of 
milestones. The assignment is expected to be completed over 12 months and benchmarked 
according to the milestones in Table A3.

6.  PPP  financial  and  commercial  structuring.  The  consultant  will  be  responsible  for 
providing capacity building on the rationale for PPPs and supporting financial analyses, such as 
review  of  projected  revenues  and  expenditure  (capital,  operations,  depreciation)  for 
reasonableness and completeness with regard to project objectives, accuracy of financial models, 
and appropriateness of risk allocation structures. Specific tasks include  
(i)   undertake an analysis of relevant infrastructure subsectors to assess their readiness 
for PPPs;  
(ii)   review  existing  PPP  project  proposals  and  financial  and  commercial  structures 
across the country to draw lessons from the various structures;  
(iii)  help selected prospective GCAs to scope projects, examine their capacity gaps and 
resource constraints, and assist select relevant staff who will be responsible for PPP 
financial and commercial structuring activities, and prepare guidelines on designing 
and managing PPPs;  
(iv)  provide hands-on training with selected government staff responsible for project 
preparation in the development of financial models and potential risk allocation 
structures;  
(v)  in consultation with other consultants, review and provide training on the desired 
benefits to end users; prepare output specifications and performance standards;  
(vi)  review,  identify,  design,  and  provide  training  on  bankable  financing  models  for 
recommended PPP structures, including appropriate off-take arrangements, debt–
equity  ratios,  loan  tenures,  financing  costs,  term  sheet  requirements  to  ensure 
project viability, and financial closure;  
(vii)  provide training in assessing alternative forms of government support and perform 
project risk analysis with suitable mitigation strategies;  
(viii)  provide training on procurement and funding options, including the role of available 
public  funds  and  their  incorporation  into  the  financial  analysis,  along  with 
commercial  borrowing,  based  on  likely  terms  and  conditions,  and  review  the 
application process; 
(ix)   assess  and  provide  training  on  relevant  commercial  issues  (such  as  project 
requirements for concession contracts), tariff structures and payment mechanisms, 
and institutional development (such as use of special purpose vehicles and escrow 
accounts) in promoting recommended PPP structures to investors and potential 
lenders;  
(x)  help prepare outline business cases for two PPP projects in priority sectors (power, 
road, water, waste management) that are bankable and support project structuring;  
(xi)  develop relevant PPP preparation processes, procedures, output specifications, key 
performance indicators, financial models, and report templates required to design 
and implement PPP projects that generate value for money, are bankable, and are 
affordable to government;  
(xii)  work with GCAs and regulatory officials, and provide training on measuring project 
performance after implementation and enforcing contract terms;  
(xiii)   train GCA staff on developing all required due diligence documents for potential 
investors and lenders; and 
 (xiv)   provide any other training and project development support as deemed necessary 
by ADB.  
7.  Technical  (engineering)  analysis.  Review  and/or  prepare  the  technical  validation  for 
project design and cost estimates, and support capacity development in prospective GCA entities 
to

12  Appendix 3 
 
(i)   identify relevant staff in selected GCAs who will be responsible for PPP technical 
activities and identify capacity gaps and resource constraints;  
(ii)  review, identify, design, and provide training on prefeasibility studies on verification 
of assumptions, population coverage, losses, current and projected demand for 
project  outputs,  technical  viability  of  the  project  design  criteria  and  standards, 
capacity, whole of life costs (inclusive of project preparation, regular and periodic 
maintenance and decommissioning costs), site requirements, and other conditions;  
(iii)  support PPP project development for the OBC case studies, providing inputs on 
project costs (capital expenditures, operation, maintenance), required contingency, 
and other information as requested;  
(iv)   support project technical analysis by developing relevant processes, procedures, 
templates, case studies, and model projects to support PPP development;  
(v)   provide training on technical issues impacting on proposed PPP project structures 
such as project costs, and preconditions for a private operator to fulfill in meeting 
service obligations;  
(vi)   provide forums to disseminate information from comprehensive technical reviews, 
including details on projected operation and maintenance costs and their economic 
costs and benefits; confirm the project design on a least-cost and whole of life cost 
basis in financial and economic terms;  
(vii)   provide  training  on  such  subjects  as  quantity  and  rates  for  major  civil  works, 
equipment, construction and supervision consulting, and other input items;  
(viii)   provide any other training and project development support as deemed necessary 
by ADB.  
 
8.  Economic  analysis.  Review  and/or  prepare  the  economic  analysis  of  selected  PPP 
projects and support capacity development in prospective GCA entities to  
(i)   undertake an analysis of relevant infrastructure sectors and subsectors to assess 
their readiness for PPPs;  
(ii)   identify relevant staff in selected GCAs who will be responsible for PPP economic 
analysis activities, and identify capacity gaps and resource constraints;  
(iii)  review,  identify,  design,  and  provide  training  on  determining  project  rationales, 
market structures, and economic costs and benefits for PPP projects;  
(iv)  support PPP project development for two OBC case studies, providing inputs on 
project costs, benefits, key performance indicators, and any other information as 
requested;  
(v)   support project economic analysis by developing relevant processes, procedures, 
templates, case studies, and model projects that can be used to support PPP 
development;  
(vi)   provide training on economic issues impacting on proposed PPP project structures;  
(vii)   participate in forums to disseminate information on economic analyses, including 
details on projected costs and benefits from a project; confirm the project design on 
a least-cost and whole of life cost basis in economic terms;  
(viii)   provide any other training and project development support as deemed necessary 
by ADB.  
 
9.   Environmental safeguards. Support capacity building in project environmental safeguards 
and environmental impact assessment in compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement 
(2009) and other requirements. Such work will  
 (i)   help selected GCAs identify staff to be responsible for environmental safeguard

Appendix 3  13 
activities of selected projects, and identify capacity gaps and resource constraints;  
(ii)  review the environmental safeguard capacity of staff identified in GCAs to manage 
the  environmental  safeguards;  and  based  on  their  mandated  environmental 
safeguards, review work and assess capacity building needs;  
(iii)   help prepare two examples of OBCs for bankable PPP projects in priority areas 
(power, road, water, and waste management);  
(iv)  based  on  the  environmental  safeguard  review  procedure,  and  the  guidelines, 
templates, and case studies developed, train safeguard staff of GCAs on how to 
screen  and  categorize  projects  (conduct  environmental  assessments  if  this  is 
required of them); conduct environmental due diligence, compliance monitoring, and 
reporting  based  on  the  safeguard  requirements  of  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement (2009) and applicable government environmental requirements;  
(v)   develop project environmental management plans (following ADB and government 
requirements) included in bid documents; provide training, including the requirement 
to comply with mitigation measures; and provide training on how to incorporate the 
environmental management plan in tender and contract documents, and how to 
supervise the preparation of or review of contractors’ environmental management 
action plans; and conduct compliance monitoring and reporting; and 
(vi)   provide any other training and project development support deemed necessary by 
ADB.  
 
10.  Social  safeguards.  Support capacity building in project social safeguards and impact 
assessment to ensure compliance with ADB and government guidelines. Such work will 
(i)   help selected GCAs identify and select relevant staff to be responsible for social 
safeguard activities, and examine capacity gaps and resource constraints;  
(ii)  review, identify, design, and provide training on relevant social analysis (such as 
gender action plans, resettlement plans, indigenous peoples development plan), 
involuntary resettlement, indigenous peoples, gender safeguards, and other basic 
training in compliance with ADB’s safeguards policies;  
(iii)  help prepare two examples of OBCs for bankable PPP projects; and support project 
social safeguard issues to develop relevant processes, procedures, and templates 
that can be used to support PPP development;  
(iv)  develop project poverty and social analysis frameworks for social impacts, impact 
monitoring,  and  mitigation  measures  for  design  and  implementation  (such  as 
resettlement  implementation)  to  maximize  project  social  benefits  and  minimize 
and/or avoid social risks;  
(v)  review  the  capacity  of  GCAs  to  implement  social  safeguard  impact  mitigation 
measures;  
(vi)  provide  training  and  support  on  issues  such  as  project  classification,  including 
involuntary  resettlement  checklist  and  key  impacts  on  indigenous  peoples  and 
project categorization forms; and 
(vii)   provide any other training and project development support as deemed necessary 
by ADB.  
11.   Legal  and/or  procurement.  Design  bid  processes,  tender  guidelines,  risk  allocation 
structures, project documentation, and bid evaluation procedures. Activities include  
(i)   review institutional requirements for implementing PPPs from a legal perspective; 
(ii)  assess capacity in prospective GCAs to address legal and/or procurement issues;  
(iii)   help selected GCAs identify staff to be responsible for PPP-related contract design,

14  Appendix 3 
 
procurement, and contract management activities; and examine capacity gaps and 
resource constraints;  
(iv)  review, identify, design, and provide training on (a) bid documents (requests for 
qualification and for proposal) and contractual agreements; (b) project marketing 
and  pre-bid  consultations;  (c)  bidder  qualification  and  bid  evaluation  criteria;  
(d) monitoring and evaluation frameworks; (e) required due diligence documents for 
potential financiers; (f) bid process, bid evaluations, and contract negotiations; and 
(g) contract management; and 
 (v)   provide any other training and project development support as deemed necessary 
by ADB.
